snippet.textDisplay:
Hey, you have enough phones to do the Google Maps hack, which is HILARIOUS. A guy in Berlin put 99 phones in a kiddie wagon and walked around Berlin streets, causing Google Maps to detect a huge mass of slow moving vehicles and suggest alternate routes. Do it!
And yes, we have reached peak smart phone. I have a phone with a fingerprint reader, decent cameras, infrared blaster, 4,000 mah battery, dual sim, great screen, great memory, snapdragon chipset. $140 new. Bought a used one for $50 as backup. Until a phone comes along that can speak for me, I'm good. I'll pass on constantly adding to landfills and resource exhaustion. If that's your thing, go for it.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hey, you have enough phones to do the Google Maps hack, which is HILARIOUS. A guy in Berlin put 99 phones in a kiddie wagon and walked around Berlin streets, causing Google Maps to detect a huge mass of slow moving vehicles and suggest alternate routes.  Do it!
 And yes, we have reached peak smart phone. I have a phone with a fingerprint reader, decent cameras, infrared blaster, 4,000 mah battery, dual sim, great screen, great memory, snapdragon chipset. $140 new. Bought a used one for $50 as backup. Until a phone comes along that can speak for me, I'm good. I'll pass on constantly adding to landfills and resource exhaustion. If that's your thing, go for it.

snippet.textDisplay: Not until we have what Ubuntu touch promised. One device with interfaces for whatever it is connected to. I want to carry my full desktop PC, entertainment system and phone in my pocket, I want my tech life in one device. I want to be able to connect to any TV or monitor and be able to choose between a full desktop display with full desktop applications or an entertainment system. I want a device and operating system made to be useful, not made to be just sexy enough to sell.
snippet.textOriginal: Not until we have what Ubuntu touch promised. One device with interfaces for whatever it is connected to. I want to carry my full desktop PC, entertainment system and phone in my pocket, I want my tech life in one device. I want to be able to connect to any TV or monitor and be able to choose between a full desktop display with full desktop applications or an entertainment system. I want a device and operating system made to be useful, not made to be just sexy enough to sell.

snippet.textDisplay: The original iPhone was the smartphone revolution. Apple nailed the form factor that would be the basic design blueprint for years to come. They nailed how we would use such a phone with touch. Real revolutions don’t happen often. Phones will continue to offer better specs like faster processors, better batteries, sharper cameras, etc but don’t expect a big revolution. Round phones don’t make sense. Triangular phones don’t make sense. Only one shape makes sense. Folding phones are just an evolution of the same thing. Cars typically have had an engine up front, a cabin, & a rear with a trunk. This is the formula that has been used for over 100 years. The basic form factor has been the same. Tesla started an electric revolution while still using the same form factor. As extreme as the Cybertruck is, it’s still the basic form factor of a truck. It’s just an extreme design. Their revolution came in the form of powertrains and technology. As with Apple everyone else has had to play catch up to Tesla. Revolutions don’t happen often but when they do happen they change the way we do things.
snippet.textOriginal: The original iPhone was the smartphone revolution. Apple nailed the form factor that would be the basic design blueprint for years to come. They nailed how we would use such a phone with touch. Real revolutions don’t happen often. Phones will continue to offer better specs like faster processors, better batteries, sharper cameras, etc but don’t expect a big revolution. Round phones don’t make sense. Triangular phones don’t make sense. Only one shape makes sense. Folding phones are just an evolution of the same thing. Cars typically have had an engine up front, a cabin, & a rear with a trunk. This is the formula that has been used for over 100 years. The basic form factor has been the same. Tesla started an electric revolution while still using the same form factor. As extreme as the Cybertruck is, it’s still the basic form factor of a truck. It’s just an extreme design. Their revolution came in the form of powertrains and technology. As with Apple everyone else has had to play catch up to Tesla. Revolutions don’t happen often but when they do happen they change the way we do things.

snippet.textDisplay: I guess the next big leap would be video glasses, but they do not have to be a standalone product. Using either a new Bluetooth standard or Wi-Fi direct, a wirelessly connected device could send a live video feed to the glasses in real-time. So you're interacting with an acceptably small pair of glasses, while the processing is done by a bigger device, such as a phone, laptop or a tower.
snippet.textOriginal: I guess the next big leap would be video glasses, but they do not have to be a standalone product. Using either a new Bluetooth standard or Wi-Fi direct, a wirelessly connected device could send a live video feed to the glasses in real-time. So you're interacting with an acceptably small pair of glasses, while the processing is done by a bigger device, such as a phone, laptop or a tower.

snippet.textDisplay: In a way Marquess is right. I still use my Pixel 2xl and am satisfied with it: 1440p display, newest software +camera software (->still good camera), good processor (not a gamer), love the fingerprint on the back below the camera, with energy saving mode the battery is still going strong even though I bought it like over 2 years ago for 670 € or sth. also the double front facing speakers are great, it's a good trade for having bezzles; and I don't need wireless charging
snippet.textOriginal: In a way Marquess is right. I still use my Pixel 2xl and am satisfied with it: 1440p display, newest software +camera software (->still good camera), good processor (not a gamer), love the fingerprint on the back below the camera, with energy saving mode the battery is still going strong even though I bought it like over 2 years ago for 670 € or sth. also the double front facing speakers are great, it's a good trade for having bezzles; and I don't need wireless charging

snippet.textDisplay: Dozens of small improvements each year for many years really add-up big time. We might hit plateaus when it comes to individual technologies, but there is literally no end to technological innovation. AI is an example of a technology impacting smartphones that's still in its infancy.
snippet.textOriginal: Dozens of small improvements each year for many years really add-up big time. We might hit plateaus when it comes to individual technologies, but there is literally no end to technological innovation. AI is an example of a technology impacting smartphones that's still in its infancy.

snippet.textDisplay:
"are we at peak smartphone ?"

No, we are at peak stupid smart phone users. Smartphone have more computing power than many laptops but still most people use thier smartphones as dickpic phones instead of computers via usb3 port HDMI out signal. I hope 2020 will be the year where stupidities such as wide viewing angles for the complete bus to read your texts without looking over your shoulder because of completely useless wide viewing angles but instead focus on intelligent functions such as wider display and multiple connectivity as to external monitor. This is the base of 5g thinking but why more connections in to the phone if you cant connect out from the phone ? And yes, there is screencast but when you hook up bluetooth mouse and keyboard all the interferences will create lag on screencast sooner or later, you need the wired connection over usb3 to monitor such as LG, HTC, Huawei, Samsung phones have.

Att the enda it is up to reviewers as you Maequees, will you continue prioritize wide viewing angles on display so nothing can be private in your phone or will you take lead and start looking at more useful functions of a smartphone such as replacing your laptop with the smartphone ? All we need is implementing HDMI via usb3 port for connectivity as standard so we can hook up to any tv and skip the laptop. The smartphone will evolve if the users evolve but if users refrain from developing there is no point developing phones further for just photos with more bling and nothing else.

snippet.textDisplay: We've been at peak smartphone for the last couple years. Anything that comes out now seems to be gimmicky because they are out of ideas and have nothing else to do. They are putting old technology that's we had in other devices maybe not phones, but the technology has been around for a while.  The only new thing is the foldable screen. That's it. And a slightly better cameras.  I'm sure s11 camera will be better than the s10 but I doubt even with its 100 megapixel camera it's going to be that's much better.

snippet.textDisplay:
Peak? please... It's only at its peak if a smartphone to you is its sensors. Even though can handle upgrades.
The battery technology is ancient. Wait till we get a new tech like graphite or who knows what which not only it will last for weeks but it will charge in a couple of minutes and you won't lose energy in heat or the battery won't be under stress above 80% or below 30%.
Wait till the chips use smaller nanometer architecture.

Software: Should I include OS and native apps that both apple and google are behind?
I should be able in Google Fit to log any aspect of my health so I can be the holder of that info and not just in a folder of my Dr's office. I want to change Dr? Good, just NFC my phone somewhere he gets my health database so he can do his full job.
I want to be able to store my eyesight changes with graphs of how it changes overtime cause I already lost my glasses prescription papers they gave my 12 years ago.

So many software ideas...
snippet.textOriginal:
Peak? please... It's only at its peak if a smartphone to you is its sensors. Even though can handle upgrades.
The battery technology is ancient. Wait till we get a new tech like graphite or who knows what which not only it will last for weeks but it will charge in a couple of minutes and you won't lose energy in heat or the battery won't be under stress above 80% or below 30%.
Wait till the chips use smaller nanometer architecture.

Software: Should I include OS and native apps that both apple and google are behind?
I should be able in Google Fit to log any aspect of my health so I can be the holder of that info and not just in a folder of my Dr's office. I want to change Dr? Good, just NFC my phone somewhere he gets my health database so he can do his full job.
I want to be able to store my eyesight changes with graphs of how it changes overtime cause I already lost my glasses prescription papers they gave my 12 years ago.

So many software ideas...

snippet.textDisplay: don't forget. If you would try to leave with the same smartphone for more than 2 years, in the vast majority of time, you would run into serious problems like: no more updates (in case of android phones), batteries that won't hold more than 65% than it did when it was new, and problems with various apps that wouldn't let you use their features because you need to update them and the OS as well, but you can't do it because of the latter. So, the clear image is: you could leave with a smartphone for more than 2 years, but a lot of the new developed features for the new phones would not be accessible...kind of like living with a motorola flip-phone in the year 2020.
snippet.textOriginal: don't forget. So, the clear image is: you could leave with a smartphone for more than 2 years, but a lot of the new developed features for the new phones would not be accessible...kind of like living with a motorola flip-phone in the year 2020.

snippet.textDisplay:
What if we think of development of any product as a series of trajectories?

The first was PDA's and early smartphones, the second was the iPhone and everything up to now, the third will be foldables and who knows what other innovations.

So we're at the peak of this development trajectory, the next one has just started.
snippet.textOriginal:
What if we think of development of any product as a series of trajectories?

The first was PDA's and early smartphones, the second was the iPhone and everything up to now, the third will be foldables and who knows what other innovations.

So we're at the peak of *this* development trajectory, the next one has just started.

snippet.textDisplay: We have not. And my reason for saying that is.. There still isn't a place online I can go to and pick out what I want in a smartphone and have them build that smartphone. When I can go online, pick those specs and have my smartphone phone built, shipped and ready to be activated by the time I get it.. That's when I'll consider that we've hit the peak of smartphones. Im still upset we can't do that with vehicles yet. Maybe I don't want a new Ford mustang. Maybe I want a new 1965 ford mustang built in 2020.. I wish companies would do this lol

snippet.textDisplay:
Wait what? 'Almost never a good reason to spend $1000 on a smartphone"? Is there ever a good reason? There is never a good reason to spend that much on a phone. People are shopping for cameras that have access to social media for the most part.
.
I notice when you demo a phone, swiping left and right is effortless. I swear my Pixel 3XL doesn't even sense my thumb. Especially with IG. If I use pen with a rubber stylus tip, there is no problem. But when I use my thumb, I sometimes have keep trying multiple times.
.
As for the peak car debate, only the luxury models have the features you mention. When there is driver assist, blind spot warnings, active braking on everything from a Bentley to a Sentra as a standard feature, then you might be able to claim we may be at peak car. But then luxury cars will still have the best safety features. The sad part is a lot of those features are not on the cars most people can afford until production costs reach a point they can be added.
snippet.textOriginal:
Wait what? 'Almost never a good reason to spend $1000 on a smartphone"? Is there ever a good reason? There is never a good reason to spend that much on a phone. People are shopping for cameras that have access to social media for the most part.
.
I notice when you demo a phone, swiping left and right is effortless. I swear my Pixel 3XL doesn't even sense my thumb. Especially with IG. If I use pen with a rubber stylus tip, there is no problem. But when I use my thumb, I sometimes have keep trying multiple times.
.
As for the peak car debate, only the luxury models have the features you mention. When there is driver assist, blind spot warnings, active braking on everything from a Bentley to a Sentra as a standard feature, then you might be able to claim we may be at peak car. But then luxury cars will still have the best safety features. The sad part is a lot of those features are not on the cars most people can afford until production costs reach a point they can be added.
